coredata.dc:title: Equation of state for systems of hard non-spherical molecules
coredata.dc:creator: Few, G.A.
Rigby, M.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The equation of state for systems of hard prolate spherocylinders has been obtained using a Monte Carlo simulation method. The result in the fluid region are compared with the predictions of scaled particle theory, and are found to agree quite well. The equation of state is significantly different from that for hard sphere molecules, and it is concluded that the effects of non-spherical shape must be explicitly dealt with.

The results in the fluid region are compared with the predictions of scaled particle theory, and are found to agree quite well. The equation of state is significantly different from that for hard sphere molecules, and it is concluded that the effects of non-spherical shape must be explicitly dealt with. I, Introduction 2. This metli- The vinai expansion for such systems was the subject od could be used inn Monte Carlo calculation, but of an earlier investigation [3], and in this note we re- does not seem to be ideal, since it is uncertain in any port the results of Monte Carlo simulation studies. given case how many terms must be taken in the se- 433 0.1 064 0.2 1.73 0.3 3.69 0.4 7~75 0.45 10.78 . 0475 0.5 0525 0.55 0.575 0.6 0.65 0.7 1255 14.58 10.53 11.50 12.28 14.10 18.04 21.76 Volume 20, number 5 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LEITERS 1 July 1973 ries. However, this method does offer great promise in the detailed interpretation of orientational correla- tion effects. An alternative, simpler, approach has been used in this work, which leads more directly to the equation of state, but gives less information about orientation- ai effects. In some ways our approach resembles that used by Vieillard-Baron [6] in his recent Monte Carlo study of systems of two-dimensional hard ellipses. For a pair of convex hard molecules we denota the shortest distance between the hard cores as p, and de- fine a distribution function, G(p), analogous to the conventional puir distribution function. Thus for a • system of N molecules in volume V the number of molecular pairs whose cores lie between p and p + dp is given by N2G(p) F(p) dp/2 V. F(p) dp is the vol- ume element available to the centres of mo]ecuies at p. In general this will depend on the shapes of the molecules, and on the degree of orientationai order in the system. For convex hard molecules without angu- lar correlations, Kihara [7] has shown that F(p) may be defined in terms of parameters characteristic of the molecular shape, and can be written F(p)2S+8ir~2+ l6iil~p+4irp2, where Sis the surface area and ~ is the mean radius. We may also define a mean intermolecular separation, F(p), which will in general also depend on the orienta- tional order of the system. in a ?vlonte Carlo simula- tion it is possible to determine values of ~(p) and G(p)F~p), as average values over a small range of p. The vinai function is zero for all values of p ~ O, and on application of the vinaI theorem we obtain an ex- pression for the equation of state in terms of the lim- iting values of G, F, ~‚ asp tends to zero. PV/NkT_ l=(N/6V~F~O)G(O)~(O). Values of Ftp) G(p) and ~(p) were obtained from the simulation for a range of values of p and the re- sults extrapolated to p 0 in order to obtain the compressibility factor. The Monte Carlo calculations followed convention- • al procedures [4] . The orientations of the molecules were.defined in terms of two integers between 1 and 100, which determined the two polar angles needed for these axially symmetric molecules. Some care was • needed in the choice of initial lattice configurations, especially at the higher densities Non cubic basiL 434 A ~~i_A ::J ~— R «O ~„ Fig. 1. The prolate sphero cylinder model. AA‘ is the axis of rotation. cells were needed in order to use potentially close packed structures for the initial configurations. The present set of results are for systems of 120 mole- cules, of prolate spherocylindrical shape (fig. 1) in whichR* = 1. Further calculations for other values ofR* are planned. Typical Monte Carlo runs were of 10~ to 5 X l0~ steps. 3. Results The data are presented in table 1, and are shown graphically in fIg. 2. The results are seen to fall on two curves, with a discontinuous region in the den- sity range near to 0.5. The lower density region ap- pears to correspond to a fluid phase, and the higher densities to a solid. The tie line joining the equilibri- um solid and fluid phases has not been located. The lowest density point on the solid branch (d 0.525) appears to be stable, and shows no tendency to melt. In comparison, the hard sphere system has a minimum stable solid density ofd= 0.54 [8} ‚and it appears that Table 1 Equation of state for hard spherocylinders, R* = d PV/IVkT--1 Volume 20, numberS CHEMICAL PHYSICS LEiTERS 1 July 1973 where7=S/i‘anddNv/V o lt has been shown that the virial coefficients de- rived from this model are in good agreement with di- reedy calculated values [3], and it is seen in fig. 2 that the equation of state is in good agreement with the simulation data in the fluid region. (For the sphero- cylinders studied here, -y = 3.6.) It should be noted that despite the relativaly small deviation from spher-• ical shape 6hown by these molecules, the equation of state differs significantly from the hard sphere equa- tion. At d = 0.45, the hard sphere pressure is about 20% smaller than that for the spherocylinders. Fur- thermore, it was pointed out by Gibbons that the properties of convex non-spherical molecules cannot be adequately reproduced using an effective spheri- -‚ cal model. Any successful treatment of non-spherical -7 molecules must include explicitly the effects of non- spherical repulsive forces. o ‚k — -- — — ~ ________________ o 28- 24 - 20 - 16- >l~ G., ~ 12- e 4, o u n u n -1 -2 •3 -4 .5 -6 d Fig. 2. Equation of state for hard spherocylinders, R4 = 1.d Nv/V. X fluid phase; o solid phase; — — — scaled particle the- ory. the freezing density for our spherocylinder mole- cules is somewhat lower than that for hard spheres. This result seems intuitively reasonable, and is also consistent with the findings of Vieillard-Baron in two dimansions. A detailed investigation of this density re- gion, with careful study of orientational correlations is in progress. Preliminary results show a pronounced increase in orientational order accompanying the freezing process. Also shown in fIg. 2 is the equation of state given by the scaled particle theory for convex hard mole- cules obtained by Gibbons [91. According to this the- ory, the equation ofstate for convex hard molecules is a function of the density, d, and of a shape factor, ‘y, determined by the mean radius, R, surface area, S, and volume per molecule, y. head.ce:title: Equation of state for systems of hard non-spherical molecules

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Chemistry Department, Queen Elizabeth College, Campden Hill, London W8 7AH, UK

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The equation of state for systems of hard prolate spherocylinders has been obtained using a Monte Carlo simulation method. The result in the fluid region are compared with the predictions of scaled particle theory, and are found to agree quite well. The equation of state is significantly different from that for hard sphere molecules, and it is concluded that the effects of non-spherical shape must be explicitly dealt with.
